"I consider that woman to be most estimable, who, while she brings into the world all the charms of society that is to say tase, grace, and genius knows at the same time how to guard her reason, and her heart against that insipid vanity, that false sensibility, that violent self love and from all those affectations, which spring up from an inordinate love of society, who against her inclinations , submits to custom and usages because it is a necessary part of wisdom; and does not in the [??n...n] time, lose sight of nature, but, still sometimes [??steering?] herself towards reflecting upon what is natural at least to honour it by her regrets.
I consider that woman to be estimable, who in cultivating philosophy, and, letters, loves them for their own sake, and not for a vain and frivolous reputation who by the study of good books endeavors to enlighten her understanding by the knowledge of truth, to strengthen her mind by principles, and leave others the jargon, the words, and the parade; in short her who will not [??carp?] in a worthless person because he happens to have

a credit, and a name, but at the hazard of displeasing, determines in her house and out of it to preserve her esteem for virtue, her contempt for vice, her sensibility for freindship[sic], and in spite of passion for an extensive society dares even in the midst of that society, have the courage to publish a mode of thinking so extraordinary, and the still greater courage to act to it."

A writer in the National Intelligencer says that spirits of hartshorn is a certain remedy for the bite of a mad dog.  The wound, he adds, should be constantly bathed with it, and three or four doses, diluted, taken inwardly during the day.  The hartshorn decomposes, chemically, the virus, insinuated into the wound, and immediately alters and destroys its deleteriousness.  The writer, who resided in Brazil for some time, first tried it for the bite of a scorpion, and found that it removed the pain and inflamation almost instantly.  Subsequently, he tried it for the bite of a rattlesnake, with similar success.  At the suggestion of the writer an old friend and physician tried it in cases of hydrophobia, and always with success.

8th rain drove us off from harvesting

19th Began haying

26th another heavy thunder storm

20th killing frost

13th another rainy day

21st turned cold. NW wind

4th rainy day
5th finished gathering corn for the spring
6th rain again - thunder showers - my stream in the yard highest I ever knew it
7th Mr. Ransom of Springfield was here - four coloured persons taken back into slavery
8th another rainy day - finished feeding cattle
10th cleared up at last - Oh how we - finished husking corn in my floor.

17th snow squally - disagreeable weather
sent to DPR 275 bricks

20th Began sowing oats 
21st thunder showers
22nd still confined in the house
25th Mr. Kirk died last night unprepared to meet his God - how awful - the consideration - visited Sarah - getting well myself.

3d plowed my garden - warm day thunder shower around
4th showery day
5th heavy rain last night - Mrs. Huntington died
7th planted Ambrose orchard - thunder showers
8th a real blow last night - N and S fury(?) all dawn - had the ague again

17th + 18th cold N.E. wind backward spring

23d Began planting in Ambrose field
24th cold N.E. wind.
25th cold E wind - Wan A. Timmy died a few days since in Pekin

17th Began stacking hay - Henry Burhans died of cholera in Chicago - getting worse in Peoria - several cases in Tremont

11th Began sowing wheat

29th sunday heavy N.E. rain storm
30th windy night - pleasant day

4th meeting to vote for tax to build school House - cooler weather yet

26th hand beans got a letter from Junius - heavy thunder showers

30th rainy day

3d last saturday night 3 buildings in Pekin struck by lightning - one boy killed. Barnums stable in Tremont struck also - and in another place a horse killed - cholera in Peoria + Pekin on the increase.

4th July - celebrated the day at Fathers - oration by Rev. Mr. Blanchard - extremely hot weather
5th stacked hay - began harvesting wheat.
9th first cucumbers
10th David Moobery died of cholera
13th finished harvesting fall wheat - thunder showers - very hot weather

22nd finished cutting spring wheat - Began cutting Oats
23d sawed turnips - hot sun to day
26th finished harvesting - very hot weather
30th finished haying
31st July - rain - laid Ambrose pasture fence
1st August - another rain - thrashed wheat for Mr. Bartlit - laid up fences
3d thunder showers - stacking hay - extremely hot weather
4th Aunt Eunice died - cloudy appearance of a thunder storm

8th still extremely hot
10th visited Cornwells - rain with thunder - got Lambs Constitution of man from Library
13th drawing in oats - hottest weather yet - sweat awfully - 15

1850
21st began shingling Ambrose house - heavy thunder shower - heavy blow a little hail - muddy muddy - grain not in growing badly
24th thunder shower last night still very warm weather
27th began shingling my wood house - cool nights now after an extremely hot summer - Mr. Sill returned from his visit to Ohio  - 70 die dialy (daily) in Milwaukee of Cholera
29th and 30th rainly days - Anns had the Cholera Morbus today - Professor Webster to be hung to day.
31st rainy raining hard - wind N.W.
1st Sept communion day - Mr. Emersns two boys sick with billious fever
2nd Junius started for Galesburn - finished shingling my woodhouse - John Durham here - taking the census
8th sunday - expect to start for N. York tomorrow - have $115.70.
9th started for N. York with $126.50 and $10.00 of DPRoberts money
10th stated at the Peoria House waiting with great impatience for a Boat - awoke before day by the whistle - but was disappointed. the Boat came down - instead of up - while waiting heard another whistle with pleasure - went on Board early in the morning - took Breakfast Paid fare to LaSalle $2.50 each
Name of Boat Erexa
Passed: Rome Chillicothe Henry Lacon Hennepin Peru and landed at LaSalle at 4 oclock expecting to start on a packet at 4 oclock. disappointed again. have to stop at the Hardy House one night a Circus over the way.

1850
this afternoon & evening visited the Catholic Cathedral in [t]own of ____(vichon?) on the hill back 50 by 100 ft and 3 in 40 ft high of lime stone
11th Dawn- appearance of rain - at 8 oclock started on the packet one passenger with his wife bound for California a brother to Gov. Burnet of California - also a Mr. Indi a resident of California was acquainted with Mr. Farnham there - about 3 oclock got to the break - waiting for waggons to take us 16 mi around the break - a little town Marseilles
12th day break at Lock Port coal N.E. went to Chicago - arrive at Chicago at 12 oclock - bought me a coat an[d] patns - for $10.00 - Join Mr. Marsh + Henry - got started on Steam Boat at 5 oclock for N. Buffalo. Paid $9.00 fare to Buffalo NY
13th very sick on the passage as well as the rest. took the cars at 9 oclock - day break at Marshall - stopped great many times at last arrived at Detroit at 1 oclock - got board the Steamer Ocean a new splendid Boat - wind very light prospect of a pleasant ride tonight.
14th 4 oclock arrived at Buffalo - Telegraphed to Chicago to Burhans - on business took supper at Huffs Hotel 7 oclock took the cars for Rochester arrived at 11 oclock stopped at the Rail Road hotel --  went chippewa + the niagara falls crossed suspension Bridge + museum ___
15th sunday started for

uncle wilson's 12 miles south got there at 2 oclock - tired walking - found them all well
16th visited around
17th Father sick - concluded to stop another day - wrote a letter to Ann - some appearance of rain
18th thunder - appearance of showers - Father some better - rode to Rochester with Harvey Pehlps - visited the Falls and Baynes Panorama - "voyage to Europe["] at 5 oclock. took packet for N. Buffalo - mailed a letter to my family
19th Loving(?) appeaance. passed Clyde Montezuma. low swamp ground outlet of T___ka and Cayuga lake - rainy afternoon
20th damp and cloudy - day light at Rome - 9 oclock got to Utica found Jerome Tyler - went into the mansion - took dinner - got into the stage for Floyd Corner(?) - got to Uncle Ebs at 4 oclock
21st clear beautiful morning - went into the woods got Himback(?) gum and some Beach nuts - afternoon rode to Stitsville(?) Mr. Tyler gone went to Trenton square - some brown Barns left of them went and saw Laura just alive when back to Uncle Ebenezers
22nd Sunday - clear and pleasant
23rd warm day - Uncle and Aunt went with me to Rome 8 miles
24th pleasant - Uncle sick with a cold. visited at Mrs. Tylers - Thunder shower after noon - staid all night and
25th started homeward to Rome - at 2 oclock took cars for Lysaun(?) arrived at 5 oclock took Packet at 7-1/2 for Buffalo
26th passed Lyons - stormy yesterday - cloudy - and dull to day.

got into Rochester at 7 oclock - waited on horses changed Packets
27th sun rose clear - cloud arose from the west cool and damp - about 10 oclock arrived at Lock Port - beautiful prospect our enjoyment was somewhat lessened by the rain. after going several miles through a deep cut in the rock we at last came into the Tonewand(?) creek. still lawry(?) - arrived at Buffalo at sun set - took passage on the May Flower at 11 oclock - high wind fromthe N.W
28th very windy this morning many sea sick - finally at 8 oclock arrived at Detroit and to our great disappointment found the cars gone so shall have to stop over sabbath here. went to the American Temperance house
29th clear beautiful morning - walked all over the town went to church - Episcopal - afternoon to the presbyterian church. at 7 oclock took the cars for N. Buffalo.
30th at 9 oclock arrived went on board - the pacific steamer got into Chicago at 2 oclock - stopped one night with Henry Burhans
1st Oct. cloudy cleared off warm at 2 oclock took packet for LaSalle
2nd at 1 oclock passed mount Joliet - cold night with bright norther lights - passed the break in the canal. - Father quite unwell - towards night arrived at LaSalle - got on board of a the steamer [space for name] for Peoria. Went to Peru for freight then to Hennepin. Took more freight - finally the fog so thick staid till morning.
3rd cool run to Lacon took more freight 9 oclock got home little after dark

6th clear and cold. First killing frost. Father under Dr. care - went to church
7th Began cutting Buck wheat
9th worked for Mr. Hawks - rainy after noon
16th very warm - thunder showers - Began work for Mr. Bartlit. 3 murders committed near Peoria a few days ago - got 2 of the murderers in jail - yesterday went to Tremont.
19th first snow squalls - clearing Buck wheat - laying Bartells (Barlits?) upper floor
21st Began digging potatoes - now and then a rotten one
22nd Mr. Frisby visitinghere
25th ground froze hard theis morning - Ambrose started yesterday for Bloomington - finished digging potatoes.
28th Ambrose returned - beautiful weather
30th thunder showers last night

4th rainy day
15th turned cold

20th cold frosty morning - the Peoria murderers have their trial today
22nd snow squally - Began finding cattle - paid M. Blandard. Butter 2.50 cash 10.00 total $12.50
25th rainy day

1st Dec. 1850 - rainy day

3d turned cold - sunday morning one killed and 2 wounded in a gragery(?) in Peoria
4th cold snow squally 8º above zero all day
7th snow storm 4 in deep - cold weather

116th finished killing hogs - get $3.25 per head

1st Jan. 1851 - clear and cold.

9th last night a heavy rain storm - wind shifted into the N.W. with snow squalls

13th Ann sit up today for the first - warm pleasant weather

17th yesterday turned very cold this morning 2º below zero - high wind
21st painted Ambrose house - got a letter from Junius last night
23d thrashing our wheat - machine broke
24th Junius got home from Galesburg - Polly has the scarlet fever
26th 7 and 8 etc. thrashing wheat

30th Jan. 13º below zero - clear N.W. wind
31st 10º below zero
1st Feb. snow storm

7th very warm weather - my youngest child quite sick - taking wheat to market at .68 cts.

10th snow storm 2 or 3 in. deep - the babe worse sent again for the Doctor

14th heavy rain storm. mud! mud!

19th Levi & Maryett visiting here heavy rain storm
20th still raining
21st rainy - wild geese and ducks flying north
23d thunder showers last night - pigeons flying - frost coming out of the ground

27th ground white with snow - towards evening -it began snowing from the N.E.
1st March - high wind from the S.W. - most horrible going - attended preparatory Lecture in Pleasant Grove
2nd N.W. wind cold
3d Mr. Moffats daughter aged 5 yrs died this morning 
4th rainiy
5th cold - the mumps in the neighborhood
16th rainy - cant go to church. Yesterday three men grafting Fathers orchard
17th grafted my orchard - some few have begun plowing
20th began raking corn stalks - started the plow but find it too wet
21st Rec'd a letter from Orville Phelps - California and one from Junius
22nd rainy wet weather for several days

ground too wet to play - I grafted Father orchard
27th grafted my orchard - heard from George Waters in California
31st Mar. - rec'd a letter from Junius - James Gay died to day - Mr. Boscom(?) of Galesburg died last Wednesday

6th sunday morning - ground white with snow - crusted over - on jury - went home
7th appearance of rain - rode to Pekin - raining nearly all day - colored woman tried for resisting officer - found guilty - I was called on jury - case of Hix + Muker(?) for damages against Hicks daughter - found $400

10th cold N.E wind appearance of rain
12th rain storm again

24th pleasant weather - first Whipporwills

28th frost this morning - we are plowing for corn
29th rain to day - Darius taken sick - snow squalls

5th frost and ice again ________
6th frost again
7th warm after a long time of cold. plowed my garden
9th visited H.B. Waters. thunder showers

12th thunder showers

15th appearance of more rain

18th thunder showers again - Oh dear me?

24th worked for M. Bartlin worn fences - quite a heavy frost - fences white with it

5th took the last of our oats to Westly(?) - dreadful bad roads. corn adraning(?) 32 c in Peoria - Cholera on the increase in Peoria - 10 deaths on ten mile of Cholera
6th lost another frisket(?) staid at home from church
7th Began harvesting wheat - extremely warm
8th and 9th thunder showers - very hot
10th I am sick threatened wit the Bilious fever - clear pleasant day - quite a curiosity
11th had a slight chill
12th the ague in earnest on me - about 12 oclock.

13th had the doctor - 9-3/4 lb  crock of Butter - extremely hot weather - 98º
20th went to meeting - Ellen taken sick
21st Ellen high fever all night - Boys mowing grass - I am getting smart
22nd rainy after quite a dry spell
23rd cut our spring wheat. I begin to work again. Junius started off peddling(?) day before yesterday
24th cut Ambrose wheat
29th ague again - rainy - our folks went Blackberrying

2nd Aug. mussed(?) my ague today
3d great rain storm from the N.E

10th rainy
11th last night a very heavy thunder storm - streams high again - I took an ague pill this morning
12th wheat growing in the shock - thunder shower of east in sight - the water fell 10 in this last rain - farm creek higher than it has been this year
13th rct a letter from Lebanon H.H - Liba(?) storms

18th potatoes all taken with the rot in the garden - still cloudy - appearance of rain - Junius gone to Havana and Beth peddling Lightning rods

1st Sept. 1851 - foggy - I started for Galesburg with Junius. stopped at Peoria a while - rode on to Brimfield - very hot and dusty. staid over night at Mr. Brooks - a little west of Brimfield
2nd arrived at Galesburg - took supper at Mr. Bascoms - staid all night at

the tavern.  took several sketches of Galesburg

4th got back to Peoria bought the cl___ etc for a pump. 28 ft chain. 1.80  14-1/2 lb wheel 1.25 ct. got home about noon
6th stacked corn grass hay - very hot
7th communion day - had my little boy named - Lester Brandt. Mr. Emerson and Gay had their children christened
12th very hot and dry roads very dusty - Abagina Burhans here visiting
13th very hot in the evening heavy thunder shower - the first rain for a long time.
14th cool N.E. wind(?) muddy roads. Agusuta has the ague again.
15th thrashed our corn in my Barn
16th Father started for Uncle Isaacs as fox river visiting
21st sunday rain storm in the morning. Martha and Hester visited here - went to Joel's

11th 7º below zeor

18th rainy + snowy

6th Feb. framing Walters house - extremely bad roads - let Charles have 100 dollars

24th raised Walters House

4th a severe chill
5th storms every night - heavy snow storm - several in. deep now.

11th warm beautiful day
16th rain

19th worked for Ambrose harvesting

1st Aug. 1852 Mr. Moffat sick lung fever - Mr. Brockway has the Cholera

8th this morning a heavy thunder shower - a great blessing - crops ever suffering badly - wells were going dry - yesterday thrashed.

for Ballard - finished stacking for ABR

2nd a fine rain last night. Oh! how good our heavenly Father is - to us sinners
Sept. 6th muddy day - still some cake left - 12 year old thrashed my oats - extremely dry - wells failing all around - my yearling colt died of snake bite
9th Esq. Hittle died - hurt at a raising - began hauling off oats at 15 cts
10th sowed wheat 5 hr. David Simmons(?) of Washington died of Cholera
11th showery day - oh! how good the rain is
12th cold chilly day - attend Wesleyan quarterly meeting
13th first frost

18th rain storm N.E. 
19th still rainy -muddy
20th still misty
21st cleared up at last
22nd sent a load of Apples to Peoria
26th quite a frost
27th gathered applies
30th let Ballard have $10.00 for a few days - finished gathering apples nearly - have 150 bu. of apples
1st Oct. 1852 - rainy - picked the first corns for the hogs
2nd still rainy our wells all going dry - great scarcity of water all around - hauled 1600 Bricks
3d Oct. put the colums under my Renters(?) House
8th rainy day - bad roads - movers going by constantly
12th Gitchell come to harvest corn - sold 20-1/2 bu apples - and opened the school house.

15th first killing frost - Walts horse fell into the ditch - hewed my sills for my house
23rd framed the sills to my house - very dry - wells going dry again
28th heavy rain last night - warm weather - framing my house
30th still rainy - nearly a week of rainy weather - and no appearance of fair weather yet.
1st Nov. 1852 - rainy day again
2nd Election day- cloudy cooll
3d rainy day 
4th still raining - mud enough
5th cleared up last night - after nearly 2 weeks storm - oh! such roads
10th snow storm - killed old __ and 2 turkeys - one a wild one
16th another snow storm 3 in. deep - went to Peoria with Beef - roads very bad
18th killed 3 beefs and a calf
24th rainy - cloudy and stormy - for 4 weeks past bad time for harvesting corn - corn spoiling - killed a opossum
1st Dec. clear and pleasant - picking corn with two hired hands - Gitchell my ____ (rustic?) has run away
3rd rainy day - went to OBriens with Mr. Moffat to get advice about gathering Gitchells corn for debt
5th sunday - very muddy - cleared up in the morning - Samson Mitchell is here shaking with the ague.
7th a great snow storm about a foot now 1 oclock still snowing - yesterday finished picking corn in the prairie lot - have 140 bu to gather of Gitchell corn
12th sunday - snow fell 2 in last night - since Monday last - it has been cloudy all the time and snow a little every day - the trees bend down with the snow - the roads - almost impassible - a foot of snow - and under it mud and water
14th found my calf - strayed - Father fell on the sled and hurt himself
15 killed hogs - very pleasant day
16th rainy cleared off after noon - wind shifted into the N.W. cold. high wind - took my pork to Wesly City

had 1160 lb at 5 c amount $58.00
18th got my stray steer home - paid $2.00 - yesterday high wind very cold
21st killed hogs for Ambrose
22nd for Darius - roads pretty good now - rain storm
25th a party at Mr. Emersons - snow storm
27th rainy days
31st finished picking corn
1st Jan. 1853 - fine day - cut out fence row north of my orchard 
3d went to Peoria - yesterday snow storm 3 or 4 in.
4th and 5th - drew me a wood pile - Fanny Hathoway not expected to live but a few days
8th Fanny Hathaway died at 12 oclock - rany afternoon - I have been putting weather boards on my house

25th went to Westly city and Groveland.

28th rainy - Oh may it be a heavy rain - picked 2 loads notwithstanding the rain.

5th finished picking corn -

15th day for eggs - 400 a barrel for cited - paid Charles Houman $25.00

18th snow storm

5th thunder showers

6th 14º above zero - and high wind - N.W. - hard for grass to grow

11th 11º below freezing - awful cold - Borrowed $64.00 of Hannah(?) G. Clark

27th sowed spring wheat - have to feed cattle yet.
28th grafted for Darius
30th cut cornstalks - rain storm.

8th rain storm - finished harvesting oats for Freduger
11th last night a heavy shower - plenty wet now - harvesting

8th sept went to Peoria took Miss Todd home - got home sick - corn fell to 40 cts wheat to 55ct apples a drag(?) - I got 75 cts for some(?)

9th subscribed by Note 50 dollarts to Chicago Theological seminary in annual instalments of 10 dollars payable 1st Jan. annually
17th and 18th county fair - plowing for wheat - rainy
21st state fair at Peoria(?) to continue 5 days - rainy still
23d first frost - partly killed the vines - did not kill the corn - attended the state fair.
24th went to the state fair again 
25th sowed 4 bu winter wheat
30th began cutting up corn
1st Oct  took a load of corn to Peoria for Darius the Banks are all breaking

12th Election of School Trustees  - began gathering apples
17th thrashed my grain had 41 bu wheat and 253 bu oats cost $9.64 old Mr. Hardey(Harding?) buried to day
20th first killing frost
21st thrashing for Walter
23d finished thrashing for W.B.R.
27th Henry Burhans and wife visiting here and aunt patty Henry Lynn and wife
28th cold and stormy
31st finished picking cider apples - yesterday went after butternuts got 8 bu
2nd school began - H.J. Burhans and wife started home
6th finished digging potatos
7th rainy day - N.E. Father and Walter got home from Chicago - with each of them a carrige
14th cold day went to Peoria took a few Apples - done a cost of shipping - left a crock Butter for Judge Powell - weight crock and all 28-1/2 lb. at 25 cts to be paid when used out.
17th made 5 bbl cider

20th 16º above zero 
22nd snow storm 4 in deep

24th 10º below zero
24th zero
26th thanksgiving day - finished hauling corn stalks
28th snow going off - south wind

7th great rain storm N.E. wind mud

23d very cold
25th had company
31st killed hogs

2nd went to Groveland sent $2 for the Pictorial by Grove

10th sunday - rainy day S.E. wind
11th got a barrel of cider made

25th very warm after a rain storm - a remarkable warm winter - so far
27th visited Charles Cornwells very warm and horrid roads
28th turned cold at last and snow squalls all day - paid WBR $10.00

14th NE snow storm

19th still snowing - the snow will be deep in the woods
21st 8º below zero storm over snow over a foot deep

20th rainy day
21st cool and pleasant

7th rainy day frm S.E.

26th 10º below freezing

2nd rain 
3d rain

24th rainy
